entry.title: Automorphisms and Key Switching in LWE based Cryptosystems
entry.content:
In my previous blogs on LWE cryptanalysis and Ring-LWE foundations, I covered the basic mathematical structures underlying modern FHE schemes. If you haven’t read those, especially the Ring-LWE and CKKS mathematical foundations post, I’d recommend checking that out first since I’ll be building directly on those concepts here.

Now, I want to tackle a super specialized but crucial topic that honestly has embarrassingly little literature online - automorphisms and key switching in Ring-LWE based systems. This is gonna get pretty heavy on Galois theory and some advanced algebraic techniques, but we’ll take it step by step.

As I covered in my Ring-LWE foundations post, almost all modern FHE schemes are built around the Ring-LWE problem over cyclotomic rings. We can perform addition and multiplication between ciphertexts homomorphically, but there’s another crucial operation that’s absolutely essential for practical applications - ciphertext rotation.

Now, rotation is used in places like shifting an image feature map in a CNN, or cycling through records in an encrypted data. But, rotating a ciphertext should feel counter-intuitive cuz encryption is designed to make data look random and to be able to rotate it should destroy the meaning right? Well, no. Cuz the way we encrypt the data using LWE can be viewed as the process of adding noise to the data, so when we rotate it, the noise kind of “shuffles” and the ciphertext would look very different than it looked before and we won’t be able to figure out any patterns.

For this very purpose of rotation, I am going to use a very elegant concept from algebra: Automorphisms. Automorphisms, we are going to see it in more details further, but for now, they are “structure-preserving” transformations that allow us to rotate the underlying data within its encrypted shell. But, this comes with an additional cost, i.e., after performing an automophism over the LWE-ciphertext, the key under which it was originally encrypted with, also gets “automorphed” or also gets rotated. Now, we can just ask the client to decrypt it using the rotated key, but that’s not practical cuz the client would have to store multiple keys and also know which key corresponds to which rotation. That’s where Key Switching comes in - it’s a technique that allows us to transform a ciphertext encrypted under one key to be decryptable under a different key, without ever revealing the plaintext.

Galois Theory and Automorphism Groups

Alright, so to really understand automorphisms in the context of Ring-LWE, we need to dive into some Galois theory. Don’t worry if you’re not super familiar with this stuff - I’ll build it up from the ground.

The Galois Group of Cyclotomic Fields

Recall from my Ring-LWE foundations post that we work in the ring R=Z[X]/(Xn+1)R = \mathbb{Z}[X]/(X^n + 1)R=Z[X]/(Xn+1) where nnn is a power of 2. The polynomial Xn+1X^n + 1Xn+1 is the 2n2n2n-th cyclotomic polynomial Φ2n(X)\Phi_{2n}(X)Φ2n​(X).

The splitting field of Φ2n(X)\Phi_{2n}(X)Φ2n​(X) over Q\mathbb{Q}Q is the cyclotomic field Q(ζ2n)\mathbb{Q}(\zeta_{2n})Q(ζ2n​), where ζ2n=e2πi/2n\zeta_{2n} = e^{2\pi i / 2n}ζ2n​=e2πi/2n is a primitive 2n2n2n-th root of unity.

The Galois group Gal(Q(ζ2n)/Q)\text{Gal}(\mathbb{Q}(\zeta_{2n})/\mathbb{Q})Gal(Q(ζ2n​)/Q) is isomorphic to the group of units (Z/2nZ)∗(\mathbb{Z}/2n\mathbb{Z})^*(Z/2nZ)∗. Each element k∈(Z/2nZ)∗k \in (\mathbb{Z}/2n\mathbb{Z})^*k∈(Z/2nZ)∗ corresponds to the automorphism σk\sigma_kσk​ defined by:

σk:ζ2n↦ζ2nk\sigma_k: \zeta_{2n} \mapsto \zeta_{2n}^kσk​:ζ2n​↦ζ2nk​

Since nnn is a power of 2, we have (Z/2nZ)∗≅Z2×Zn/2(\mathbb{Z}/2n\mathbb{Z})^* \cong \mathbb{Z}_2 \times \mathbb{Z}_{n/2}(Z/2nZ)∗≅Z2​×Zn/2​ when n≥4n \geq 4n≥4.

Structure of the Automorphism Group

For n=2dn = 2^dn=2d with d≥2d \geq 2d≥2, the group (Z/2nZ)∗(\mathbb{Z}/2n\mathbb{Z})^*(Z/2nZ)∗ has order ϕ(2n)=n\phi(2n) = nϕ(2n)=n and can be generated by:

  • g1=−1 mod 2ng_1 = -1 \bmod 2ng1​=−1mod2n (order 2): corresponds to complex conjugation
  • g2=5 mod 2ng_2 = 5 \bmod 2ng2​=5mod2n (order n/2n/2n/2): corresponds to "rotations"

Every automorphism can be written uniquely as σk\sigma_kσk​ where k=(−1)b0⋅5b1k = (-1)^{b_0} \cdot 5^{b_1}k=(−1)b0​⋅5b1​ for b0∈{0,1}b_0 \in \{0,1\}b0​∈{0,1} and b1∈{0,1,…,n/2−1}b_1 \in \{0, 1, \ldots, n/2-1\}b1​∈{0,1,…,n/2−1}.

Automorphisms on Polynomial Rings

When we extend these automorphisms to act on polynomials in Z[X]/(Xn+1)\mathbb{Z}[X]/(X^n + 1)Z[X]/(Xn+1), we get:

σk:f(X)↦f(Xk) mod (Xn+1)\sigma_k: f(X) \mapsto f(X^k) \bmod (X^n + 1)σk​:f(X)↦f(Xk)mod(Xn+1)

The key property is that this action preserves the ring structure: for any polynomials f,gf, gf,g:

  • σk(f+g)=σk(f)+σk(g)\sigma_k(f + g) = \sigma_k(f) + \sigma_k(g)σk​(f+g)=σk​(f)+σk​(g)
  • σk(f⋅g)=σk(f)⋅σk(g)\sigma_k(f \cdot g) = \sigma_k(f) \cdot \sigma_k(g)σk​(f⋅g)=σk​(f)⋅σk​(g)

Computing Automorphisms Efficiently

To compute σk(f(X))\sigma_k(f(X))σk​(f(X)) where f(X)=∑i=0n−1fiXif(X) = \sum_{i=0}^{n-1} f_i X^if(X)=∑i=0n−1​fi​Xi, we need to evaluate:

σk(f(X))=∑i=0n−1fiXki mod (Xn+1)\sigma_k(f(X)) = \sum_{i=0}^{n-1} f_i X^{ki} \bmod (X^n + 1)σk​(f(X))=∑i=0n−1​fi​Xkimod(Xn+1)

Since Xn=−1X^n = -1Xn=−1, powers XkiX^{ki}Xki with ki≥nki \geq nki≥n wrap around: Xki=(−1)⌊ki/n⌋Xki mod nX^{ki} = (-1)^{\lfloor ki/n \rfloor} X^{ki \bmod n}Xki=(−1)⌊ki/n⌋Xkimodn.

The naive approach takes O(n2)O(n^2)O(n2) time, but we can do better using bit-reversal patterns when kkk has special structure.

Automorphisms in Cyclotomic Rings

Now let’s see how these automorphisms actually work in practice and why they’re so useful for ciphertext rotations.

Action on CKKS Slots

Remember from my Ring-LWE foundations post that CKKS uses the Chinese Remainder Theorem to pack n/2n/2n/2 complex numbers into the n/2n/2n/2 slots corresponding to roots {ζ2n,ζ2n3,…,ζ2n2n−1}\{\zeta_{2n}, \zeta_{2n}^3, \ldots, \zeta_{2n}^{2n-1}\}{ζ2n​,ζ2n3​,…,ζ2n2n−1​}.

When we apply automorphism σk\sigma_kσk​ to a polynomial, it permutes these slots according to the map:

slot i↦slot (ki mod 2n)\text{slot } i \mapsto \text{slot } (ki \bmod 2n)slot i↦slot (kimod2n)

But since we only have nnn actual roots (the odd powers), the effective permutation on the n/2n/2n/2 conjugate pairs is more complex.

Generators and Rotations

The most practically important automorphisms are:

  1. Complex Conjugation (k=−1k = -1k=−1): Maps ζ2n2i+1↦ζ2n2n−1−(2i+1)=ζ2n2i+1‾\zeta_{2n}^{2i+1} \mapsto \zeta_{2n}^{2n-1-(2i+1)} = \overline{\zeta_{2n}^{2i+1}}ζ2n2i+1​↦ζ2n2n−1−(2i+1)​=ζ2n2i+1​​
  2. Rotations (k=5jk = 5^jk=5j): Cyclically shift the slots

For rotations, the key insight is that k=5jk = 5^jk=5j generates a cyclic subgroup of order n/2n/2n/2 in (Z/2nZ)∗(\mathbb{Z}/2n\mathbb{Z})^*(Z/2nZ)∗. This gives us exactly the rotations we want for SIMD operations.

Frobenius Endomorphisms

There’s a beautiful connection to Frobenius endomorphisms here. In characteristic ppp, the Frobenius map x↦xpx \mapsto x^px↦xp is always a ring endomorphism. Our automorphisms σk\sigma_kσk​ can be viewed as “multiplicative Frobenius” maps.

When working modulo q=∏piq = \prod p_iq=∏pi​, we can apply the Chinese Remainder Theorem again:

Zq[X]/(Xn+1)≅∏iZpi[X]/(Xn+1)\mathbb{Z}_q[X]/(X^n + 1) \cong \prod_i \mathbb{Z}_{p_i}[X]/(X^n + 1)Zq​[X]/(Xn+1)≅∏i​Zpi​​[X]/(Xn+1)

The automorphism σk\sigma_kσk​ acts componentwise, and on each component Zpi[X]/(Xn+1)\mathbb{Z}_{p_i}[X]/(X^n + 1)Zpi​​[X]/(Xn+1), it’s a genuine ring automorphism.

Orbit-Stabilizer Analysis

The automorphism group acts on the set of n/2n/2n/2 slot positions. For practical CKKS implementations, we usually care about:

  • Full rotations: Generated by σ5\sigma_5σ5​, giving all n/2n/2n/2 rotations
  • Power-of-2 rotations: σ52i\sigma_{5^{2^i}}σ52i​ for efficient “butterfly” patterns
  • Conjugation: σ−1\sigma_{-1}σ−1​ for complex conjugation

The orbit of any slot under the full automorphism group has size n/2n/2n/2 (assuming n≥4n \geq 4n≥4), meaning every slot can be rotated to every other slot.

The Key Switching Problem

Here’s the fundamental issue that makes automorphisms tricky in practice: when we apply an automorphism to a Ring-LWE ciphertext (a(x),b(x))(a(x), b(x))(a(x),b(x)), we get:

(σk(a(x)),σk(b(x)))(\sigma_k(a(x)), \sigma_k(b(x)))(σk​(a(x)),σk​(b(x)))

But now, this ciphertext is encrypted under the key σk(s(x))\sigma_k(s(x))σk​(s(x)), not the original key s(x)s(x)s(x)!

The Mathematical Problem

Starting with a Ring-LWE sample: b(x)=a(x)⋅s(x)+e(x)+Δ⋅m(x)b(x) = a(x) \cdot s(x) + e(x) + \Delta \cdot m(x)b(x)=a(x)⋅s(x)+e(x)+Δ⋅m(x)

After applying automorphism σk\sigma_kσk​:

σk(b(x))=σk(a(x))⋅σk(s(x))+σk(e(x))+Δ⋅σk(m(x))\sigma_k(b(x)) = \sigma_k(a(x)) \cdot \sigma_k(s(x)) + \sigma_k(e(x)) + \Delta \cdot \sigma_k(m(x))σk​(b(x))=σk​(a(x))⋅σk​(s(x))+σk​(e(x))+Δ⋅σk​(m(x))

This follows because automorphisms are ring homomorphisms, so they preserve multiplication and addition.

The Problem: Our rotated ciphertext (σk(a(x)),σk(b(x)))(\sigma_k(a(x)), \sigma_k(b(x)))(σk​(a(x)),σk​(b(x))) now encrypts the rotated message σk(m(x))\sigma_k(m(x))σk​(m(x)) (which is what we want!) but under the rotated key σk(s(x))\sigma_k(s(x))σk​(s(x)) (which we don’t want).

The client only possesses the original secret key s(x)s(x)s(x), not the entire orbit {σk(s(x)):k∈(Z/2nZ)∗}\{\sigma_k(s(x)) : k \in (\mathbb{Z}/2n\mathbb{Z})^*\}{σk​(s(x)):k∈(Z/2nZ)∗}.

Formalizing Key Switching

Definition: Given ciphertexts (a,b)(a, b)(a,b) encrypting message mmm under key s′s's′, key switching produces ciphertext (a′,b′)(a', b')(a′,b′) encrypting the same message mmm under key sss.

The challenge is doing this without ever learning mmm, sss, or s′s's′ in the clear.

Security Requirement: The key switching operation should be semantically secure - an adversary seeing the input ciphertext, output ciphertext, and public switching key learns nothing about the message or secret keys.

The General Key Switching Framework

Key switching works by publishing auxiliary information called switching keys that encode the relationship between sss and s′s's′ in a way that allows transforming ciphertexts without revealing the keys themselves.

The idea is to encrypt s′s's′ under sss, then use this to “substitute” s′s's′ for sss in the ciphertext equation.

Formal Security Analysis of Key Switching

Now let’s dive deep into the mathematical foundations and security analysis of key switching. This is where things get really rigorous.

Digit Decomposition and Base-B Representation

The naive approach to key switching has a serious problem: noise explosion. If we directly encrypt each coefficient of s′s's′, the noise grows linearly with the coefficient magnitude, which can be as large as qqq.

The solution is digit decomposition. We choose a base BBB (typically B=2ℓB = 2^{\ell}B=2ℓ for some small ℓ\ellℓ) and decompose elements a∈Zqa \in \mathbb{Z}_qa∈Zq​ as:

a=∑i=0L−1aiBi where ai∈{0,1,…,B−1} and L=⌈log⁡Bq⌉a = \sum_{i=0}^{L-1} a_i B^i \text{ where } a_i \in \{0, 1, \ldots, B-1\} \text{ and } L = \lceil \log_B q \rceila=∑i=0L−1​ai​Bi where ai​∈{0,1,…,B−1} and L=⌈logB​q⌉

This is the standard base-B representation, but we need to be careful about the range of coefficients.

    • Sample ei←DZn,σkse_i \leftarrow D_{\mathbb{Z}^n, \sigma_{\text{ks}}}ei​←DZn,σks​​

  1. Decompose: Compute b=∑i=0L−1biBib = \sum_{i=0}^{L-1} b_i B^ib=∑i=0L−1​bi​Bi where bi∈{0,1,…,B−1}nb_i \in \{0, 1, \ldots, B-1\}^nbi​∈{0,1,…,B−1}n
  2. Linear Combination: Compute

    (a′,b′)=∑i=0L−1bi⋅swki=(∑i=0L−1bi⋅ai,∑i=0L−1bi⋅b~i)(a', b') = \sum_{i=0}^{L-1} b_i \cdot \text{swk}_i = \left(\sum_{i=0}^{L-1} b_i \cdot a_i, \sum_{i=0}^{L-1} b_i \cdot \tilde{b}_i\right)(a′,b′)=∑i=0L−1​bi​⋅swki​=(∑i=0L−1​bi​⋅ai​,∑i=0L−1​bi​⋅b~i​)

    where swki=(ai,b~i)\text{swk}_i = (a_i, \tilde{b}_i)swki​=(ai​,b~i​)

Correctness Analysis

Let’s verify that decryption works correctly. We have:

b′=∑i=0L−1bi⋅b~i=∑i=0L−1bi⋅(ai⋅s+ei+Bi⋅s′)b' = \sum_{i=0}^{L-1} b_i \cdot \tilde{b}_i = \sum_{i=0}^{L-1} b_i \cdot (a_i \cdot s + e_i + B^i \cdot s')b′=∑i=0L−1​bi​⋅b~i​=∑i=0L−1​bi​⋅(ai​⋅s+ei​+Bi⋅s′)

Expanding:

b′=s∑i=0L−1bi⋅ai+∑i=0L−1bi⋅ei+s′∑i=0L−1bi⋅Bib' = s \sum_{i=0}^{L-1} b_i \cdot a_i + \sum_{i=0}^{L-1} b_i \cdot e_i + s' \sum_{i=0}^{L-1} b_i \cdot B^ib′=s∑i=0L−1​bi​⋅ai​+∑i=0L−1​bi​⋅ei​+s′∑i=0L−1​bi​⋅Bi

Since ∑i=0L−1biBi=b\sum_{i=0}^{L-1} b_i B^i = b∑i=0L−1​bi​Bi=b and a′=∑i=0L−1bi⋅aia' = \sum_{i=0}^{L-1} b_i \cdot a_ia′=∑i=0L−1​bi​⋅ai​, we get:

b′=s⋅a′+∑i=0L−1bi⋅ei⏟KS noise+s′⋅bb' = s \cdot a' + \underbrace{\sum_{i=0}^{L-1} b_i \cdot e_i}_{\text{KS noise}} + s' \cdot bb′=s⋅a′+KS noisei=0∑L−1​bi​⋅ei​​​+s′⋅b

Now, since the input ciphertext satisfies b=a⋅s′+e+Δmb = a \cdot s' + e + \Delta mb=a⋅s′+e+Δm, we have:

b′=s⋅a′+∑i=0L−1bi⋅ei+s′⋅(a⋅s′+e+Δm)b' = s \cdot a' + \sum_{i=0}^{L-1} b_i \cdot e_i + s' \cdot (a \cdot s' + e + \Delta m)b′=s⋅a′+∑i=0L−1​bi​⋅ei​+s′⋅(a⋅s′+e+Δm)

But wait - we need b′=a′⋅s+e′+Δmb' = a' \cdot s + e' + \Delta mb′=a′⋅s+e′+Δm for some small noise e′e'e′. The issue is the s′⋅a⋅s′s' \cdot a \cdot s's′⋅a⋅s′ term.

The Key Insight: We don’t apply key switching to general ciphertexts (a,b)(a, b)(a,b). We apply it to linearized ciphertexts where the “aaa part” is either 0 or known.

Specialized Key Switching for Automorphisms

For automorphism-based rotations, we have a special structure. Starting with ciphertext (a,b)(a, b)(a,b) under key sss, we apply σk\sigma_kσk​ to get (σk(a),σk(b))(\sigma_k(a), \sigma_k(b))(σk​(a),σk​(b)) under key σk(s)\sigma_k(s)σk​(s).

The key switching algorithm becomes:

Input: (σk(a),σk(b))(\sigma_k(a), \sigma_k(b))(σk​(a),σk​(b)) under σk(s)\sigma_k(s)σk​(s)
Goal: (a′,b′)(a', b')(a′,b′) under sss

We use a specialized approach:

  1. Compute b∗=σk(b)−σk(a)⋅sb^* = \sigma_k(b) - \sigma_k(a) \cdot sb∗=σk​(b)−σk​(a)⋅s
  2. Apply standard key switching to b∗b^*b∗ viewed as encrypting some message under key σk(s)−s\sigma_k(s) - sσk​(s)−s

This requires a more complex analysis, but the noise growth is controlled.

Noise Growth Analysis

The key switching operation adds noise with magnitude roughly:

∥KS noise∥≤n⋅B⋅σksL\|\text{KS noise}\| \leq n \cdot B \cdot \sigma_{\text{ks}} \sqrt{L}∥KS noise∥≤n⋅B⋅σks​L​

Trade-off: Smaller BBB means smaller noise per digit but more digits (larger LLL). The optimal choice balances these:

Bopt≈log⁡qlog⁡σksB_{\text{opt}} \approx \sqrt{\frac{\log q}{\log \sigma_{\text{ks}}}}Bopt​≈logσks​logq​​

Security Reduction

Theorem: If Ring-LWE is (λ,ϵ)(\lambda, \epsilon)(λ,ϵ)-secure with error parameter σ\sigmaσ, then key switching is (λ,ϵ′)(\lambda, \epsilon')(λ,ϵ′)-secure with ϵ′=L⋅ϵ\epsilon' = L \cdot \epsilonϵ′=L⋅ϵ.

Proof Sketch: An adversary breaking key switching can distinguish at least one switching key element swki\text{swk}_iswki​ from uniform. By a hybrid argument over the LLL elements, this gives a Ring-LWE distinguisher with advantage ϵ/L\epsilon/Lϵ/L.

Advanced: Bootstrapping Key Switching

In the context of bootstrapping (refreshing ciphertext noise), key switching becomes even more complex. The bootstrapping procedure requires switching from a “small” key with coefficients in {0,1}\{0, 1\}{0,1} to the “large” key used for homomorphic operations.

This requires gadget-based key switching where the switching key has a tensor product structure, enabling more efficient noise control.

The analysis involves spectral norms of the gadget matrix and requires more sophisticated techniques from the geometry of numbers.

CKKS Scheme Overview

The CKKS (Cheon-Kim-Kim-Song) scheme is a particularly elegant homomorphic encryption scheme that supports approximate arithmetic on complex numbers. It’s built on Ring-LWE and allows us to pack multiple values into a single ciphertext using the Chinese Remainder Theorem.

In CKKS, a plaintext is encoded as a polynomial where the coefficients encode the real and imaginary parts of complex numbers. When we perform automorphisms on CKKS ciphertexts, we’re essentially rotating these packed values.

For example, if we have n/2n/2n/2 slots packed with complex numbers z0,z1,…,zn/2−1z_0, z_1, \ldots, z_{n/2-1}z0​,z1​,…,zn/2−1​, then applying automorphism σk\sigma_kσk​ gives us a rotation of these slots.

Security Considerations

Now, implementing this stuff comes with some serious security considerations that you absolutely cannot ignore if you’re planning to use this in any real application:

  1. Parameter Selection: The values of nnn, qqq, and noise distribution need to be chosen carefully to resist lattice attacks. What I’ve used here are toy parameters for demonstration.

  2. Key Switching Noise Growth: Each key switching operation adds noise to the ciphertext. Too many operations can make the noise so large that decryption fails.

  3. Switching Key Size: The switching keys can be quite large - for each automorphism you want to support, you need O(n)O(n)O(n) Ring-LWE samples.

  4. Side-Channel Attacks: The implementation I’ve shown doesn’t protect against timing attacks or other side-channel attacks. Production implementations need constant-time operations.

  5. Random Number Generation: Using a proper cryptographically secure random number generator is crucial. The std::random_device I’ve used might not be sufficient for real applications.

Real-World Applications

This combination of automorphisms and key switching is super useful in practice:

  • Private Neural Network Inference: Rotating feature maps in encrypted CNNs
  • Encrypted Database Queries: Shifting encrypted records to find matches
  • Secure Multi-Party Computation: Redistributing encrypted data among parties
  • Privacy-Preserving Machine Learning: Performing encrypted matrix operations

The math might seem daunting at first, but once you get the hang of it, it’s actually quite elegant. The ring structure gives us this beautiful algebraic machinery that lets us perform complex operations on encrypted data.

I gotta say, working with these algebraic structures makes you appreciate how deep the connection between abstract algebra and practical cryptography really is. Like, who would have thought that Galois theory and cyclotomic polynomials would be so useful for encrypting your Netflix recommendations?

Anyway, I hope this blog gives you a good intuition for how automorphisms and key switching work together to enable these powerful FHE operations. There’s obviously way more depth to explore - digit decomposition, noise analysis, parameter selection, optimized implementations, etc. But this should give you a solid foundation to build on.

If you’re interested in diving deeper, I’d highly recommend checking out the original CKKS paper and maybe playing around with some of the production FHE libraries like Microsoft SEAL or IBM’s HElib. They have way more optimized implementations than my toy code here.

entry.title: Ring-LWE and CKKS: Mathematical Foundations for Homomorphic Encryption
entry.content:
Alright, so I’ve been diving deep into the mathematical foundations behind modern FHE schemes, and honestly, the more I understand the underlying algebra, the more elegant this whole thing becomes. In my previous blog on LWE cryptanalysis, I touched on the basic Learning With Errors problem, but now I want to get into the real mathematical meat of Ring-LWE and the CKKS scheme.

This is gonna be pretty heavy on the math - we’re talking cyclotomic polynomials, Galois theory, Chinese Remainder Theorem, and some serious algebraic number theory. But stick with me, cuz understanding this foundation is crucial for grasping how modern FHE schemes actually work under the hood.

I’m writing this as a mathematical foundation piece because I realized that in my upcoming blogs on automorphisms and key switching, I keep having to explain these core concepts. So here’s the deep mathematical dive that’ll serve as the foundation for those more specialized topics.

Table of Contents

  • From LWE to Ring-LWE: Why Rings?
  • Cyclotomic Polynomials and Algebraic Structure
  • The Chinese Remainder Theorem Perspective
  • CKKS Encoding: Complex Numbers in Polynomials
  • Discrete Gaussian Distributions and Noise
  • Security Foundations: Ideal Lattices
  • Parameter Selection and Trade-offs
  • Implementation Considerations
  • References

From LWE to Ring-LWE: Why Rings?

So we all know that standard LWE works with vectors in Zqn\mathbb{Z}_q^nZqn​. An LWE sample looks like (a,b)(\mathbf{a}, b)(a,b) where b=⟨a,s⟩+e+Δmb = \langle \mathbf{a}, \mathbf{s} \rangle + e + \Delta mb=⟨a,s⟩+e+Δm. This is great and all, but there are some serious practical issues:

  1. Key Size: The secret key s\mathbf{s}s has nnn elements
  2. Ciphertext Size: Each ciphertext is (n+1)(n+1)(n+1) elements
  3. Operations: Matrix-vector multiplications are expensive

Ring-LWE fixes this by moving from vectors to polynomials. Instead of working in Zqn\mathbb{Z}_q^nZqn​, we work in the polynomial ring Rq=Zq[X]/(f(X))R_q = \mathbb{Z}_q[X]/(f(X))Rq​=Zq​[X]/(f(X)) for some polynomial f(X)f(X)f(X).

Now here’s the key insight: a polynomial of degree n−1n-1n−1 can be represented by nnn coefficients, just like a vector of length nnn. But polynomial arithmetic gives us way more structure to work with.

A Ring-LWE sample looks like:

(a(X),b(X)) where b(X)=a(X)⋅s(X)+e(X)+Δ⋅m(X) mod f(X)(a(X), b(X)) \text{ where } b(X) = a(X) \cdot s(X) + e(X) + \Delta \cdot m(X) \bmod f(X)(a(X),b(X)) where b(X)=a(X)⋅s(X)+e(X)+Δ⋅m(X)modf(X)

The magic happens because polynomial multiplication in RqR_qRq​ can be done super efficiently using Number Theoretic Transform (NTT), which is basically FFT over finite fields.

Cyclotomic Polynomials and Algebraic Structure

Now, the choice of f(X)f(X)f(X) is crucial. We typically use f(X)=Xn+1f(X) = X^n + 1f(X)=Xn+1 where nnn is a power of 2. This isn’t random - Xn+1X^n + 1Xn+1 is the 2n2n2n-th cyclotomic polynomial Φ2n(X)\Phi_{2n}(X)Φ2n​(X).

What are Cyclotomic Polynomials?

Think of cyclotomic polynomials as the “primes” of polynomial rings. Just like how prime numbers are the indivisible building blocks of integers, cyclotomic polynomials are irreducible polynomials that can’t be factored further over the rationals.

But here’s the cool part - while prime numbers feel abstract and random, cyclotomic polynomials have this beautiful geometric interpretation. The mmm-th cyclotomic polynomial Φm(X)\Phi_m(X)Φm​(X) “knows about” the mmm-sided regular polygon!

Visualizing the Geometric Picture

Imagine you’re standing at the center of a circle, looking at the vertices of a regular 2n2n2n-sided polygon inscribed in that circle. Each vertex corresponds to a 2n2n2n-th root of unity - a complex number ζ2nk=e2πik/2n\zeta_{2n}^k = e^{2\pi i k / 2n}ζ2nk​=e2πik/2n.

Now, most of these vertices are “derived” - if you know where vertex 1 is, you can get vertex 2 by just squaring it, vertex 3 by cubing it, etc. But some vertices are primitive - they can’t be obtained as powers of vertices from smaller polygons.

The cyclotomic polynomial Φ2n(X)\Phi_{2n}(X)Φ2n​(X) is exactly the polynomial whose roots are these primitive vertices!

For our specific case where m=2nm = 2nm=2n and nnn is a power of 2:

Φ2n(X)=Xn+1\Phi_{2n}(X) = X^n + 1Φ2n​(X)=Xn+1

The primitive 2n2n2n-th roots of unity are exactly the odd powers: {ζ2n,ζ2n3,ζ2n5,…,ζ2n2n−1}\{\zeta_{2n}, \zeta_{2n}^3, \zeta_{2n}^5, \ldots, \zeta_{2n}^{2n-1}\}{ζ2n​,ζ2n3​,ζ2n5​,…,ζ2n2n−1​}.

Why odd powers? Because if kkk is even, then ζ2nk=(ζn)k/2\zeta_{2n}^k = (\zeta_{n})^{k/2}ζ2nk​=(ζn​)k/2 is actually an nnn-th root of unity, so it “belongs” to a smaller polygon!

The Ring Structure: Why Xn=−1X^n = -1Xn=−1 is Magic

Working in R=Z[X]/(Xn+1)R = \mathbb{Z}[X]/(X^n + 1)R=Z[X]/(Xn+1) means we’re doing polynomial arithmetic with the rule that Xn=−1X^n = -1Xn=−1. This seems weird at first, but it’s actually brilliant!

Think of it this way: in regular polynomial multiplication, if you multiply two polynomials of degree ddd, you get a polynomial of degree 2d2d2d. That’s annoying for storage - your polynomials keep getting bigger.

But with the rule Xn=−1X^n = -1Xn=−1, any polynomial automatically “wraps around” to stay within degree n−1n-1n−1. It’s like doing arithmetic on a clock, but instead of 12+1=112 + 1 = 112+1=1, we have Xn=−1X^n = -1Xn=−1.

Here’s the intuition for why it’s −1-1−1 and not 000: remember those primitive 2n2n2n-th roots of unity? They satisfy ζ2n=1\zeta^{2n} = 1ζ2n=1, which means (ζn)2=1(\zeta^n)^2 = 1(ζn)2=1. Since ζn≠1\zeta^n \neq 1ζn=1 (that would make it an nnn-th root), we must have ζn=−1\zeta^n = -1ζn=−1.

The beautiful structure we get:

  1. Wrapping Multiplication: Xi⋅Xj=X(i+j) mod nX^i \cdot X^j = X^{(i+j) \bmod n}Xi⋅Xj=X(i+j)modn if i+j<ni+j < ni+j<n, otherwise Xi⋅Xj=−X(i+j) mod nX^i \cdot X^j = -X^{(i+j) \bmod n}Xi⋅Xj=−X(i+j)modn
  2. FFT-Friendly: The Number Theoretic Transform works perfectly because our roots of unity are evenly spaced around the circle
  3. Lattice Structure: The ring elements correspond to lattice points with special geometric properties

The automorphism group is isomorphic to (Z/2nZ)∗(\mathbb{Z}/2n\mathbb{Z})^*(Z/2nZ)∗, which has order nnn. Each automorphism σk\sigma_kσk​ is defined by σk:X↦Xk\sigma_k: X \mapsto X^kσk​:X↦Xk where gcd⁡(k,2n)=1\gcd(k, 2n) = 1gcd(k,2n)=1.

The Chinese Remainder Theorem Perspective

This is where the magic really happens, and it’s the key insight that makes CKKS so powerful. Let me give you the intuition first, then the math.

The “Multiple Personalities” View

Imagine you have a polynomial p(X)p(X)p(X). Instead of thinking of it as a single mathematical object, the Chinese Remainder Theorem says you can think of it as having nnn different “personalities” - one for each root of Xn+1X^n + 1Xn+1.

It’s like how Clark Kent and Superman are the same person, just in different contexts. Your polynomial p(X)p(X)p(X) is “the same” as the vector (p(ζ1),p(ζ2),…,p(ζn))(p(\zeta_1), p(\zeta_2), \ldots, p(\zeta_n))(p(ζ1​),p(ζ2​),…,p(ζn​)) where the ζi\zeta_iζi​ are the roots of Xn+1X^n + 1Xn+1.

Mathematically, this gives us an isomorphism:

C[X]/(Xn+1)≅Cn\mathbb{C}[X]/(X^n + 1) \cong \mathbb{C}^nC[X]/(Xn+1)≅Cn

Any polynomial p(X)∈C[X]/(Xn+1)p(X) \in \mathbb{C}[X]/(X^n + 1)p(X)∈C[X]/(Xn+1) is uniquely determined by its evaluations:

p(X)↔(p(ζ2n),p(ζ2n3),…,p(ζ2n2n−1))p(X) \leftrightarrow (p(\zeta_{2n}), p(\zeta_{2n}^3), \ldots, p(\zeta_{2n}^{2n-1}))p(X)↔(p(ζ2n​),p(ζ2n3​),…,p(ζ2n2n−1​))

Why This is Revolutionary for Computation

Here’s the killer insight: polynomial operations become pointwise vector operations!

Want to add two polynomials? Just add their evaluation vectors component-wise. Want to multiply? Multiply component-wise. This is called SIMD (Single Instruction, Multiple Data) - you get nnn operations for the price of one.

Complex Conjugate Pairs: The CKKS Packing Trick

Here’s where CKKS gets really clever. Remember our 2n2n2n-sided polygon? The vertices come in conjugate pairs - if you have a vertex at angle θ\thetaθ, you also have one at angle −θ-\theta−θ.

This means if ζ\zetaζ is a root of Xn+1X^n + 1Xn+1, then so is ζ‾\overline{\zeta}ζ​ (its complex conjugate).

Now here’s the packing magic: if we restrict to polynomials with real coefficients (which is what we do in practice), then evaluating our polynomial at conjugate pairs gives conjugate values:

p(ζ)=p(ζ‾)‾p(\zeta) = \overline{p(\overline{\zeta})}p(ζ)=p(ζ​)​

This means we only need to store half the evaluation vector! If we know p(ζ)p(\zeta)p(ζ), we automatically know p(ζ‾)=p(ζ)‾p(\overline{\zeta}) = \overline{p(\zeta)}p(ζ​)=p(ζ)​.

Result: We can pack n/2n/2n/2 complex numbers into a single polynomial of degree n−1n-1n−1. It’s like getting a 2x compression for free, just by exploiting the symmetry of the roots!

CKKS Encoding: Complex Numbers in Polynomials

The CKKS scheme exploits this conjugate structure beautifully. Think of it as a universal translator between two languages: the language of polynomials and the language of complex vectors.

The Encoding Intuition

Imagine you have n/2n/2n/2 complex numbers that represent, say, the pixels of an image or the coefficients of a Fourier transform. You want to encrypt them homomorphically, but Ring-LWE only knows how to encrypt polynomials.

CKKS says: “No problem! I’ll convert your complex vector into a polynomial, encrypt that polynomial, and when you do operations on the polynomial, they’ll automatically happen to your original complex numbers.”

It’s like having a magical box where you put in a complex vector, it gets converted to a polynomial, encrypted, and when you add two such boxes, the encrypted polynomials add in a way that makes the underlying complex vectors add too.

Canonical Embedding: The Universal Translator

The canonical embedding σ\sigmaσ is our universal translator. It takes a polynomial p(X)=∑i=0n−1piXip(X) = \sum_{i=0}^{n-1} p_i X^ip(X)=∑i=0n−1​pi​Xi and evaluates it at all our special roots:

σ(p)=(p(ζ2n),p(ζ2n3),…,p(ζ2n2n−1))\sigma(p) = (p(\zeta_{2n}), p(\zeta_{2n}^3), \ldots, p(\zeta_{2n}^{2n-1}))σ(p)=(p(ζ2n​),p(ζ2n3​),…,p(ζ2n2n−1​))

This is like asking: “If this polynomial were a person, what would it say when you ask it about each of these nnn roots?”

Encoding Complex Vectors

To encode a vector z=(z0,z1,…,zn/2−1)∈Cn/2\mathbf{z} = (z_0, z_1, \ldots, z_{n/2-1}) \in \mathbb{C}^{n/2}z=(z0​,z1​,…,zn/2−1​)∈Cn/2, we:

  1. Extend to Conjugates: Create z~=(z0,…,zn/2−1,zn/2−1‾,…,z0‾)∈Cn\tilde{\mathbf{z}} = (z_0, \ldots, z_{n/2-1}, \overline{z_{n/2-1}}, \ldots, \overline{z_0}) \in \mathbb{C}^nz~=(z0​,…,zn/2−1​,zn/2−1​​,…,z0​​)∈Cn
  2. Inverse Canonical Embedding: Compute p=σ−1(z~)p = \sigma^{-1}(\tilde{\mathbf{z}})p=σ−1(z~)
  3. Scaling and Rounding: Scale by Δ\DeltaΔ and round to get integer coefficients

The inverse canonical embedding can be computed efficiently using the Vandermonde matrix:

V=(1ζ2nζ2n2⋯ζ2nn−11ζ2n3(ζ2n3)2⋯(ζ2n3)n−1⋮⋮⋮⋱⋮1ζ2n2n−1(ζ2n2n−1)2⋯(ζ2n2n−1)n−1)V = \begin{pmatrix}1 & \zeta_{2n} & \zeta_{2n}^2 & \cdots & \zeta_{2n}^{n-1} \\1 & \zeta_{2n}^3 & (\zeta_{2n}^3)^2 & \cdots & (\zeta_{2n}^3)^{n-1} \\\vdots & \vdots & \vdots & \ddots & \vdots \\1 & \zeta_{2n}^{2n-1} & (\zeta_{2n}^{2n-1})^2 & \cdots & (\zeta_{2n}^{2n-1})^{n-1}\end{pmatrix}V=​11⋮1​ζ2n​ζ2n3​⋮ζ2n2n−1​​ζ2n2​(ζ2n3​)2⋮(ζ2n2n−1​)2​⋯⋯⋱⋯​ζ2nn−1​(ζ2n3​)n−1⋮(ζ2n2n−1​)n−1​​

Then p=V−1z~\mathbf{p} = V^{-1} \tilde{\mathbf{z}}p=V−1z~, which can be computed using FFT in O(nlog⁡n)O(n \log n)O(nlogn) time.

Homomorphic Operations

Once we have polynomials encoding our complex vectors, homomorphic operations correspond to:

  • Addition: Enc(z1)+Enc(z2)=Enc(z1+z2)\text{Enc}(\mathbf{z}_1) + \text{Enc}(\mathbf{z}_2) = \text{Enc}(\mathbf{z}_1 + \mathbf{z}_2)Enc(z1​)+Enc(z2​)=Enc(z1​+z2​)
  • Multiplication: Enc(z1)⋅Enc(z2)=Enc(z1⊙z2)\text{Enc}(\mathbf{z}_1) \cdot \text{Enc}(\mathbf{z}_2) = \text{Enc}(\mathbf{z}_1 \odot \mathbf{z}_2)Enc(z1​)⋅Enc(z2​)=Enc(z1​⊙z2​)

where ⊙\odot⊙ is component-wise multiplication.

Discrete Gaussian Distributions and Noise

Here’s where we get into the “why is this secure?” part. The whole security of Ring-LWE comes down to adding the right kind of noise to our encryptions.

The Noise Intuition

Think of noise in encryption like static on a radio. If you’re trying to eavesdrop on a radio transmission, a little bit of static makes it hard to understand, but the intended recipient (who knows what to listen for) can still decode the message.

But here’s the crucial insight: not all noise is created equal. Random uniform noise would work, but it turns out that Gaussian noise is optimal for lattice-based cryptography. Why? Because it plays nicely with the geometric structure of lattices.

Discrete Gaussian Distribution: Nature’s Favorite Noise

The discrete Gaussian distribution DZ,σD_{\mathbb{Z}, \sigma}DZ,σ​ is like a bell curve, but restricted to integers. Picture a normal distribution centered at 0, and then only keep the probability mass at integer points.

The parameter σ\sigmaσ controls the “width” of the bell curve:

  • Small σ\sigmaσ: Noise is concentrated near 0 (good for correctness, bad for security)
  • Large σ\sigmaσ: Noise is spread out (good for security, bad for correctness)

Mathematically: Pr⁡[x]≈1σexp⁡(−πx2/σ2)\Pr[x] \approx \frac{1}{\sigma} \exp(-\pi x^2 / \sigma^2)Pr[x]≈σ1​exp(−πx2/σ2)

Why Gaussian? The Geometric Intuition

Here’s the deep reason why Gaussian noise is special: it’s the “most round” distribution.

When we add Gaussian noise to each coefficient of our polynomial, we’re essentially placing our secret in a “fuzzy cloud” that looks the same from every direction. This isotropy (rotational symmetry) is exactly what we need to make lattice problems hard.

If we used, say, uniform noise on {−B,…,B}\{-B, \ldots, B\}{−B,…,B}, our noise cloud would be cube-shaped, and cubes have corners where an attacker might find patterns. Gaussian clouds are perfectly round - no corners to exploit!

Error Polynomial Sampling

For Ring-LWE, we sample error polynomials e(X)=∑i=0n−1eiXie(X) = \sum_{i=0}^{n-1} e_i X^ie(X)=∑i=0n−1​ei​Xi where each coefficient ei←DZ,σe_i \leftarrow D_{\mathbb{Z}, \sigma}ei​←DZ,σ​ independently.

The norm of the error polynomial in the canonical embedding is:

∥σ(e)∥∞=max⁡i∣e(ζ2n2i+1)∣\|\sigma(e)\|_{\infty} = \max_{i} |e(\zeta_{2n}^{2i+1})|∥σ(e)∥∞​=maxi​∣e(ζ2n2i+1​)∣

By concentration inequalities, with high probability:

∥σ(e)∥∞≤σnlog⁡n\|\sigma(e)\|_{\infty} \leq \sigma \sqrt{n \log n}∥σ(e)∥∞​≤σnlogn​

This bound is crucial for correctness - we need the noise to be small enough that decryption works, but large enough for security.

Security Foundations: Ideal Lattices

Now for the million-dollar question: why is Ring-LWE hard to break? The answer lies in geometry - specifically, the geometry of high-dimensional lattices.

The Lattice Intuition

Think of a lattice as a regular arrangement of points in space, like the integer grid Z2\mathbb{Z}^2Z2 in the plane. But instead of 2D, we’re working in nnn-dimensional space where nnn might be 1024 or 4096.

When we use Ring-LWE, we’re essentially hiding our secret in the lattice structure. The Ring-LWE samples give an adversary some information about which lattice we’re using, but not enough to reconstruct the secret.

From Polynomials to Geometric Points

Here’s the key connection: every polynomial p(X)=∑piXip(X) = \sum p_i X^ip(X)=∑pi​Xi corresponds to a point (p0,p1,…,pn−1)(p_0, p_1, \ldots, p_{n-1})(p0​,p1​,…,pn−1​) in nnn-dimensional space via the coefficient embedding.

The polynomial ring structure gives us a lattice with special properties - it’s not just any random lattice, but an ideal lattice with tons of symmetry. This extra structure is both a blessing (it makes things efficient) and potentially a curse (it might make attacks easier).

The Fundamental Lattice Problems

Breaking Ring-LWE is equivalent to solving one of these problems on ideal lattices:

  1. Shortest Vector Problem (SVP): Given a lattice, find the shortest non-zero vector
  2. Closest Vector Problem (CVP): Given a lattice and a target point, find the closest lattice point

In 2D, these problems are easy - you can just look at the lattice and see the answer. But in 1024-dimensional space? Good luck! The number of lattice points to check grows exponentially with dimension.

Worst-Case to Average-Case Reduction

Here’s the beautiful part: Lyubashevsky, Peikert, and Regev showed that solving Ring-LWE on average is as hard as solving worst-case problems on ideal lattices.

Specifically, there’s a quantum reduction from:

  • Worst-case: γ\gammaγ-approximate Shortest Vector Problem (SVP) on ideal lattices in Z[X]/(Xn+1)\mathbb{Z}[X]/(X^n + 1)Z[X]/(Xn+1)
  • Average-case: Ring-LWE with Gaussian error width σ=γ⋅poly(n)\sigma = \gamma \cdot \text{poly}(n)σ=γ⋅poly(n)

This gives us confidence that Ring-LWE is hard even against quantum adversaries (though the reduction is quantum).

Geometry of the Canonical Embedding

The canonical embedding σ\sigmaσ maps the ring to Cn\mathbb{C}^nCn, but we can view this as R2n\mathbb{R}^{2n}R2n by separating real and imaginary parts.

The key insight is that σ\sigmaσ is an isometry up to scaling: for any p∈Rp \in Rp∈R:

∥σ(p)∥22=n⋅∥p∥22\|\sigma(p)\|_2^2 = n \cdot \|p\|_2^2∥σ(p)∥22​=n⋅∥p∥22​

where ∥p∥22=∑i=0n−1pi2\|p\|_2^2 = \sum_{i=0}^{n-1} p_i^2∥p∥22​=∑i=0n−1​pi2​ is the coefficient norm.

This geometric structure is what makes lattice algorithms like LLL and BKZ work on ideal lattices.

Parameter Selection and Trade-offs

Choosing parameters for Ring-LWE schemes involves balancing security, correctness, and efficiency.

Security Level

The security level depends on the root Hermite factor γ\gammaγ of the best known lattice attacks. For λ\lambdaλ-bit security, we need:

γ2n≥2λ/2\gamma^{2n} \geq 2^{\lambda / 2}γ2n≥2λ/2

Current estimates give γ≈1.0045\gamma \approx 1.0045γ≈1.0045 for BKZ attacks, so for 128-bit security:

n≥λ2log⁡2(γ)≈1282⋅0.0065≈10000n \geq \frac{\lambda}{2 \log_2(\gamma)} \approx \frac{128}{2 \cdot 0.0065} \approx 10000n≥2log2​(γ)λ​≈2⋅0.0065128​≈10000

But this is overly conservative. Practical parameter sets like those in Microsoft SEAL use n∈{1024,2048,4096,8192}n \in \{1024, 2048, 4096, 8192\}n∈{1024,2048,4096,8192} with carefully chosen moduli.

Modulus Selection

The ciphertext modulus qqq needs to be large enough to:

  1. Avoid Modular Reduction Errors: q>σn⋅2depthq > \sigma \sqrt{n} \cdot 2^{\text{depth}}q>σn​⋅2depth
  2. Enable NTT: q≡1(mod2n)q \equiv 1 \pmod{2n}q≡1(mod2n) for efficient polynomial multiplication
  3. Resist Attacks: Not too small relative to nnn

A common approach is to use a product of primes: q=∏i=1kqiq = \prod_{i=1}^k q_iq=∏i=1k​qi​ where each qi≡1(mod2n)q_i \equiv 1 \pmod{2n}qi​≡1(mod2n).

Noise Growth Analysis

In CKKS, after ddd levels of multiplication, the noise magnitude grows roughly as:

Noise≈σ⋅nd/2⋅Bd\text{Noise} \approx \sigma \cdot n^{d/2} \cdot B^dNoise≈σ⋅nd/2⋅Bd

where BBB is the bound on message coefficients. This exponential growth limits the multiplicative depth.

Implementation Considerations

Number Theoretic Transform

Polynomial multiplication in Zq[X]/(Xn+1)\mathbb{Z}_q[X]/(X^n + 1)Zq​[X]/(Xn+1) can be done efficiently using NTT. For this to work, we need:

  1. q≡1(mod2n)q \equiv 1 \pmod{2n}q≡1(mod2n)
  2. A primitive 2n2n2n-th root of unity ω\omegaω in Zq\mathbb{Z}_qZq​

Then NTT is just FFT over Zq\mathbb{Z}_qZq​, giving us O(nlog⁡n)O(n \log n)O(nlogn) polynomial multiplication.

Memory and Bandwidth

Ciphertext size is a practical concern. A Ring-LWE ciphertext consists of two polynomials, so 2nlog⁡q2n \log q2nlogq bits. For n=4096n = 4096n=4096 and log⁡q=200\log q = 200logq=200, that’s about 200KB per ciphertext.

Techniques like ciphertext packing and batching help amortize this cost across multiple plaintexts.

Precision and Scaling

CKKS uses fixed-point arithmetic, so precision loss accumulates. The precision budget determines how many operations you can perform before precision becomes unacceptable.

After each multiplication, you typically need to rescale by dividing by some factor (and rounding), which reduces the ciphertext modulus but maintains precision.

The math here gets pretty involved, but basically you’re managing a trade-off between precision, noise, and remaining multiplicative depth.

Looking Ahead

This foundation sets us up perfectly for understanding more advanced topics like:

  • Automorphisms: How to rotate encrypted data using Galois theory
  • Key Switching: Converting between different key representations
  • Bootstrapping: Refreshing noise to enable unlimited computation
  • Multi-Party Computation: Distributed computation on encrypted data

The algebraic structure we’ve explored - cyclotomic rings, canonical embeddings, discrete Gaussians - forms the mathematical backbone of all these techniques.

I have to say, working through this math really drives home how elegant modern cryptography is. Like, the fact that we can pack complex numbers into polynomials, perform arithmetic homomorphically, and base security on lattice problems - it’s just beautiful mathematics serving practical ends.

In my next post, I’ll dive into automorphisms and key switching, building directly on these foundations. The Galois group action on cyclotomic rings gives us this incredible ability to rotate encrypted data, but it comes with the price of changing the encryption key. Key switching is the technique that lets us convert back to the original key, and the math behind it is pretty wild.

Anyway, hope this gives you a solid mathematical foundation for understanding modern FHE schemes. There’s obviously way more depth here - ideal lattices, algebraic number theory, concrete security analysis - but this should be enough to follow the more advanced techniques.

In this blog, I am emphasizing the fact that whenever one has to encrypt something really important, or let’s say they own a startup and want to encrypt their company’s data, one must always use the standardized crypto libraries and tools like OpenSSL, RustCrypto, OQS (for post-quantum), etc. Cuz, by doing some clever thinking, your own code encoding an “Attack Proof” crypto scheme, can be broken. And, I’ll show that by breaking an LWE encryption which I coded in C++. Infact, I’ll break it in two different ways.

But before that, what is LWE?

LWE (Learning With Errors)

LWE or Learngin With Errors, is a hard mathematical problem. The mathematical definition from Wikipedia is as follows:

Let Zq\mathbb{Z}_qZq​ denote the ring of integers modulo qqq and let Zqn\mathbb{Z}_q^nZqn​ denote the set of nnn-vectors over Zq\mathbb{Z}_qZq​. There exists a certain unknown linear function f:Zqn→Zqf : \mathbb{Z}_q^n \to \mathbb{Z}_qf:Zqn​→Zq​, and the input to the LWE problem is a sample of pairs (x,y)(\mathbf{x}, y)(x,y), where x∈Zqn\mathbf{x} \in \mathbb{Z}_q^nx∈Zqn​ and y∈Zqy \in \mathbb{Z}_qy∈Zq​, so that with high probability y=f(x)y = f(\mathbf{x})y=f(x). Furthermore, the deviation from the equality is according to some known noise model. The problem calls for finding the function fff, or some close approximation thereof, with high probability.

This seems complex, but tbh, still better than other mathematical definitions for other stuff. One can get the idea from the above definition, that LWE problem is to find a solution to a set of linear equations with noise added to the system. Now, one might ask why this is hard to solve, proving that is out of scope for this blog, but for the curious who don’t fear a long mathematical detour, here you go: Classical Hardness of LWE.

LWE Encryption

Now, that we know the crux of the problem, let’s jump straight into encryption using this problem.

So, an LWE ciphertext consists of a random public vector a∈Zqna \in \mathbb{Z}_q^na∈Zqn​ and an additional element b=a⋅s+Δ⋅m+eb = a \cdot s + \Delta \cdot m + e b=a⋅s+Δ⋅m+e mod qq q. Let’s break this down further:

  • ss s is the **secret key**. Here, it is being randomly sampled from {0,1}n\{0, 1\}^n{0,1}n.
  • mm m is the message. It is important to note that the message space has to be considerably small as compared to the integer ring Zq\mathbb{Z}_q Zq​ in order to stop the ciphertext becoming random noise instead of encrypted data. In fact, we define another number pp p, which is in general a power of 2. The power represents the number of bits required to represent any element from the message space.
  • Δ\Delta Δ is the scaling factor, which equals qp\frac{q}{p} pq​. So, by multiplying this scaling factor to our message, what is happening is, we are shifting the message bits to the most significant portions of an n bit structure.
  • ee e is the noise term and it is sampeled from a discrete Gaussian distribution with small standard distribution. Now, noise should not be too large that it affects the Most Significant Bits of the encoded message during the addition.

LWE Decryption

Decryption process is fairly simple. First, assuming that the receiver obviously has the secret key (NOTE: We have discussed the symmetric scheme here, it is also possible to devise an assymetric scheme usng LWE). The receiver will re-compute the dot product of the secret key and the public vector. Then, subtract the result from b. After that, perform an operation known as ROUND, which removes the error. Then we can just rescale the end result to get our decrypted plain-text.

Now that we are done with encryption and decryption using LWE, we can move forward having a look at the code and attacking strategies. Cryptanalysis of Lazily Coded LWE

So before we dive into this interesting topic. Let’s make a few things clear.

  • It is obvious that the code presented above is publicly available, owing to the Kerckhoff’s Principle which states that cryptosystem should be secure even if everything about the system, except the key, is public knowledge.

  • Access to ciphertexts: We assume a chosen-plaintext or known-plaintext scenario, meaning we either know the original message or can encrypt arbitrary messages and collect ciphertexts.

  • Implementation-level behavior: We consider not just the mathematics, but also how the algorithm is implemented — which opens up potential side channels like timing variations or key reuse.

  • Goal of cryptanalysis: We aim to recover the secret key s, distinguish ciphertexts from random noise, or infer plaintexts under various attack models, using practical and scalable methods — including statistical, lattice-based, and implementation-aware attacks.

Machine Learning Attack

Data generation

Analyzing the data we collected and the data we’ll use for the training, we can infer that we are casting this LWE secret key problem as a supervised classification task. Where, each bit position of the secret key is treated as a separate binary classification problem.

For those not so familiar with ML concepts (like me lol), supervised classification task is a task, where we have a labeled dataset: each input (feature vector) is mapped with the correct output label. And the goal is to train the model to learn mapping from input to labels, so it can classify new, unseen inputs. And binary classification means that output (lables) are from a finite set of two elements, 0 and 1 in our case.

Model for Single Bit Prediction

Now neural network (a fancy function approximator) takes in input values, and it learns to give the correct output through repeated training on examples.

In our case:

entry.title: Lottery Ticket Hypothesis Part 2
entry.content:
Iterative Pruning and Finding the Winning Ticket

So far, we’ve talked about the idea that there’s a smaller subnetwork—our so-called winning ticket—hidden within a big neural network. But how do we actually find this winning ticket? That’s where iterative pruning steps in.

The Iterative Pruning Process

Instead of pruning once and hoping we get lucky, iterative pruning does the following:

  • Train the full network for a fixed number of iterations.
  • Prune a small percentage (say, 10%-20%) of the lowest magnitude weights.
  • Reset the remaining weights back to their original initialization.
  • Repeat steps 1–3 for several rounds.

This slow and steady process lets us uncover subnetworks that are small but still highly capable—our winning tickets.

Why Iterative Pruning Works Better

Turns out, one-shot pruning (cutting lots of weights at once) often fails to find the best subnetworks, especially when we go too small. Iterative pruning, on the other hand, carefully preserves the parts of the network that matter, leading to better performance at smaller sizes.

In the experiments, they could reduce the network size by up to 90%, and the resulting subnetworks still learned faster and better than the full network!

Do Winning Tickets Generalize Better?

Now here’s where things get spicy. When comparing test accuracies, the researchers noticed something curious:

  • The winning tickets not only learned faster,
  • They often had better generalization than the original model!

This means that they didn’t just memorize training data—they actually learned to perform better on unseen test data.

This idea is related to something called Occam’s Hill—too big and you overfit, too small and you underfit. Winning tickets land at a sweet spot: small enough to avoid overfitting, but just right to still learn effectively.

Initialization Matters (A Lot)

Another key takeaway: it’s not just the structure of the subnetwork that matters. It’s also the exact initial weights.

If you take a winning ticket’s structure and randomly reinitialize it, it loses its magic—learning slows down and performance drops.

Expanding to Convolutional Networks

The authors didn’t just test on simple fully-connected networks like LeNet on MNIST. They also ran experiments on convolutional networks like Conv-2, Conv-4, and Conv-6 on CIFAR-10.

Surprise surprise: they found winning tickets there too. In fact, the same pattern repeated:

  • Winning tickets learn faster
  • They reach higher accuracy
  • They generalize better
  • Initialization still matters

The success wasn’t limited to toy datasets—this was happening on moderately complex image classification tasks too.

Drop-Out + Pruning

What happens when you combine dropout with pruning?*

Turns out, dropout helps too! Dropout already encourages the network to be robust to missing connections. So when you prune, the network is more resilient.

When they trained networks with dropout and applied iterative pruning, the test accuracy improved even further. This hints that dropout may help in preparing the network for successful pruning.

The Big Leagues: VGG-19 and RESNET-18

Taking it up a notch, the paper also tested on deeper, real-world architectures:

  • VGG-19
  • ResNet-18

The pattern mostly held up—but with a twist. For these deep networks, iterative pruning only worked well if they used learning rate warm-up.

Without warm-up, pruning failed to find winning tickets. With warm-up (i.e., slowly increasing the learning rate at the beginning of training), they were back in business.

So yes—winning tickets exist even in deep networks, but only if you treat them with care.

Key Takeaways

  • Big neural networks contain hidden winning tickets—smaller subnetworks that can be trained to match or exceed full network performance.
  • You find them by pruning and resetting repeatedly.
  • These subnetworks not only match accuracy, but often learn faster and generalize better.
  • The initialization is crucial—you can’t just randomly reinitialize and expect the same results.
  • Even deeper networks like VGG and ResNet have winning tickets, but they may require careful tuning (e.g., learning rate warm-up).
  • Pruning isn’t just for compression—it might teach us something deep about how neural networks work.

Now, what I am trying to do is replecating the results found by the authors myself. So stick around and keep a look over my GitHub.

I am reading it as a person who only knows the basics of AI and Neural Networks, hence the following blog is written in a very intuitive manner (at least to satisfy my intuition) and obviously if I am serious enough to write a blog and leave all the other somewhat more important stuff aside for now, I won’t half assedly read the paper and the just yap over the blog. Also if the further sentences don’t sound like me, that’s cuz I asked ChatGPT to turn my notes into a blog, so there is everything I have understood from the paper but in different wordings, so that should be fine ig…. enjoy! Also a side note, this new style just capitalize everything written in Markdown bold, so I am not screaming at you just highlighting that point.

Pruning

Deep neural networks, especially fully connected ones, tend to be overparameterized. While this over-parameterization can be useful for training, it also makes models heavy and resource-intensive. To tackle this, we use pruning—a process where we remove unnecessary weights from the network.

Surprisingly, pruning can reduce parameter counts by over 90% without harming the model’s accuracy. But this raises a natural question:

If we can prune a trained model down to a smaller size without losing accuracy, why not just train a smaller model from the start?

Turns out, that doesn’t quite work.

Why Not Train Small from the Beginning

Experiments show that architectures uncovered by pruning—despite being smaller and sufficient are harder to train from scratch. When randomly initialized and trained in isolation, these pruned networks often fail to reach the same level of accuracy as the full-sized original network.

However, there’s a clever workaround.

After pruning a model, we can retain the original weights (instead of random reinitialization) and then retrain the original model. This makes the learning process much faster than randomly initializing the values over some distribution.

An Experiment in Sparsity

To understand this better, let’s consider a basic experiment:

  • Start with a fully connected convolutional neural network (CNN).
  • Perform unstructured pruning by randomly removing connections.
  • Train the pruned network while tracking the iteration with the minimum validation loss.
  • Evaluate the final test accuracy at this “best” iteration.

The observations were telling:

Sparser networks learn slower and tend to be less accurate.

Below are plots illustrating this trend. In the first two graphs, as the percentage of remaining weights decreases, the number of iterations to reach peak performance increases. In the last two, we see test accuracy steadily drop with increased pruning.

The Lottery Ticket Hypothesis

From this behavior emerges the Lottery Ticket Hypothesis, first introduced by Jonathan Frankle and Michael Carbin in 2018. The hypothesis makes a bold but fascinating claim:

A randomly-initialized, dense neural network contains a subnetwork (a “winning ticket”) that is initialized such that—when trained in isolation—it can match the test accuracy of the original network after training for at most the same number of iterations.

Let’s formalize this:

  • Start with a dense feedforward neural network f(x;θ)f(x;\theta) f(x;θ), where the initial parameters θ0\theta_0 θ0​ are sampled randomly from a distribution Dθ0D_{\theta_0} Dθ0​​.

  • Train this network using Stochastic Gradient Descent (SGD), a technique that updates weights using small, random batches of data rather than the full dataset at each step.

  • Let the training reach its minimum validation loss ll l at iteration jj j with test accuracy aa a.

Now introduce a binary mask m∈0,1∣θ∣m \in {0, 1}^{|\theta|} m∈0,1∣θ∣, which indicates which parameters are kept (1) and which are pruned (0). We now train a new network, f(x;m⋅θ)f(x; m \cdot \theta) f(x;m⋅θ), using the same initialization for the remaining parameters.

According to the Lottery Ticket Hypothesis, there exists such a mask mm m for which:

  • The pruned model reaches minimum validation loss l′l' l′ at iteration j′j' j′, where j′≤jj' \leq j j′≤j,
  • It achieves a test accuracy a′≥aa' \geq a a′≥a,
  • And it uses fewer parameters than the original model ∣m∣0<∣θ∣|m|_0 < |\theta| ∣m∣0​<∣θ∣.

In simpler terms: hidden within every big neural network is a smaller, efficient subnetwork—a winning ticket—that can be trained just as well if it’s initialized correctly.

What Counts as a Winning Ticket?

These “winning tickets” are usually uncovered through standard pruning techniques applied to fully-connected or convolutional feedforward networks.

It’s crucial to note that simply reinitializing these sub-networks randomly strips away their special status. When reinitialized, these subnetworks lose their performance edge, emphasizing the importance of the initial weight configuration.

Now, we get a feel for why we are calling them lottery tickets, because out of random initial parameters, for only a specific initialization of parameters result in the sub-network matches the performance of the original network

How to identify the Winning Tickets

  • Randomly initialize a neural network f(x;θ0)f(x;\theta_0)f(x;θ0​) where (θ0∼Dθ\theta_0 \sim D_\thetaθ0​∼Dθ​).

  • Train the network for jjj iterations, arriving at parameters θj\theta_jθj​.

  • Prune p%p\%p% of the parameters in θj\theta_jθj​, creating a mask mmm.

  • Reset the remaining parameters to their values in θ0\theta_0θ0​, creating the winning ticket f(x;m⋅θ0)f(x; m\cdot \theta_0)f(x;m⋅θ0​).

This approach of identifying the winning tickets is a one-shot approach. But, the original paper focuses more upon the iterative pruning, i.e., repeatedly train, prune and reset the network for over nnn rounds; each round we prune p1n%p^\frac{1}{n}\%pn1​% of the weights that survived the previous rounds.

Results suggest that iterative pruning finds winning tickets that match the accuracy of the original network at smaller sizes than does one-shot pruning.

entry.title: In-Memory Computation using Analog Part-1
entry.content:
Von Neumann Bottleneck

There has been an improvement in the number of transistors on a chip. More transistors mean that we have increased our ability to store more memory in less physical space. Memory storage is more efficient than ever.

Today, AI and machine learning are being studied. This requires us to store and process a large density of data, which is possible given the environment: processors and storage solutions. Also, Von Neumann Architecture requires us to store data in a separate block, and the processor needs an individual block. These different blocks are connected by buses. Given this architecture, to process these large-density data, the transfer rates must also be at par with the processing speed, maybe even faster. However, over the years, the increase in transfer speedhas only made a few gains.

When the processor has to stay idle to fetch the data from the memory block, this condition is called the Von-Neumann Bottleneck.

Some attempts to surpass this limitation have been made like:

  • Caching: Chaches are temporary storage units between the main memory block and the processor. It can store a subset of data so that future requests for that data can be served faster. For example, they store results of earlier computations or a copy of data stored elsewhere.

  • Hardware Acceleration: Hardware like GPUs, FPGAs, and ASICs are brought into the picture for faster response from the hardware side.

But these come with some limitations:

  • Limitations of Caching:

    • Size: Larger caches increase hit rates but consume more silicon area and power.

    • In multicore systems, maintaining consistency across caches is difficult.

    • Memory Latency and Bandwidth Issues: If the working set exceeds capacity, frequent primary memory access still causes stalls.

  • Hardware Accelerators’ Limitations:

    • Domain-Specificity: FPGAs, TPUs, and GPUs lack generality. They are often made for specific tasks, which, economically speaking, makes them challenging to produce.

    • At the end of the day, communications are still being made over buses, so the transfer limitation persists.

    • Software and Compatibility Issues: These devices run on specific firmware and can cause compatibility issues.

    • Power and Heat Management: These hardware accelerators generate much heat and consume much power, which obviously isn’t preferable.

Now, we dive into analog methods of overcoming this phenomenon. Of course, some digital methods have been proposed but let’s stick to the title of the blog for now and maybe (definitely) I’ll discuss digital methods in a future blog.

Analog Implementation of MACS

MAC, or Multiply-Accumulate Operation, is a common step which computes the product of two numbers and adds that product to an accumulator. MAC operations account for over 90% of Neural Network and AI computations. Yeah, so they are “kind of” important.

In the following circuit, we have 10 MOSFETs in total (5 PMOS, 5 CMOS), let us label them: PM1, PM2, PM3, PM4, PM5, NM1, NM2, NM3, NM4, NM5.

These MOSFETs are linearly biased (if you somewhat unfamiliar with working of MOSFET, go watch Engineering Mindset’s video on MOSFET on YouTube, I found it very good for a quick get around). We are applying differential inputs +Δx,−Δx,+Δw,−Δw+\Delta x, -\Delta x, +\Delta w , -\Delta w +Δx,−Δx,+Δw,−Δw.

The given transistors are now arranged in the following circuit (Image Courtesy: Reference [1]):

Now, let’s get into some transistor math.

Since, all the transistors are operating in linear region, drain current Id2 is given by:

Id2=Kn∗[Vb−Δw−Vthn−Vb+Δx2]∗(Vb+Δx)I_{d2} =K_{n}*[V_{b}-\Delta w - V_{thn} - \frac{V_{b} + \Delta x}{2}]*(V_{b}+\Delta x) Id2​=Kn​∗[Vb​−Δw−Vthn​−2Vb​+Δx​]∗(Vb​+Δx)

For knowing what each term means, refer to [1].

Now, we are taking the transconductance factors and threshold voltages of the N and P MOSFETS to be equal, we get the following expression for the output current:
